text: I'm Joshua Margolis I'm a professor in the organizational behavior unit here at the school and I want to add my welcome
to uh Dean noras and president fa it's a special privilege for me today not only
to see um familiar faces but also to be the moderator for this panel discussion
with uh three such distinguished uh alumni who as you will hear very soon
from them exemplify our school's mission to exercise leadership that makes a
difference in the world the origin of this panel uh is a
very simple but Stark reality life happens but all too infrequent are our
opportunities to actually acknowledge the unexpected ways that life intervenes
as we try to pursue the aspirations and plans that students set out when they're
here on campus so this session is designed to start a conversation not
just to acknowledge the unexpected challenges that arise in our lives but to start a conversation that allows us
to reflect upon the unexpected in our lives and to draw lessons from the
unexpected that arises that we encounter in our lives I'd first like to introduce
each of our panelists and then tell you a little bit about how I hope we can run this session so it truly becomes a
discussion first Lisa caroy MBA 1994
section A I'm proud to say a section mate and friend of mine Lisa is the head of global Capital markets for Bank of
America Merl Lynch she's a member there of the global corporate and Investment Banking operating committee and the
capital commitment committee for Bank of America she's also executive sponsor for the women's leadership ship Council in
global banking and markets Lisa has worked in Investment Banking since
receiving her ba from Columbia University with tours at Drexel Burnham
and Bear Sterns and she's now a trustee at her beloved Columbia University
chairing the alumni Affairs and development committee she's a proud New Yorker living on the upper west side
with her husband David a journalist and their four children Melissa Wexner MBA
1982 section B Melissa is a writer a speaker and an advocate in the area of
Substance Abuse Prevention and treatment and she teaches high school math she is
um Fielding uh questions as we speak from her students um because she's here
she is the author of a book about her daughter's struggle with drugs about which you will hear in a very inspiring
way in just a few minutes Melissa attended Welsley college and earned her Bachelor's in economics from from MIT a
master's in systems engineering from the University of Houston and worked for kako after graduating with her MBA from
Harvard she worked at huet Packard and Apollo computer and in 1988 she
co-founded s synetic a high performance networking company that was later
acquired by 3om she left high-tech in 2000 and switched careers to teaching and she's been a very active member of
our alumni association here in Boston in the middle Kathy juy MBA
1985 section A Kathy is the founder and chief executive officer of the multiple
Myoma Research Foundation and the multiple Myoma research Consortium she has more than two decades
of experience in the pharmaceutical industry previously holding senior positions at GD sirl and Merc Kathy has
received many awards for her Innovative leadership most recently being named to the 2011 time 100 list of the world's
most influential people she's received this school's alumni Achievement Award
and the healthc care business women's association's Woman of the Year award her efforts have been featured on NBC
CBS FOX News and CNN and she's been written about in the Wall Street Journal
the New Yorker Harvard Business review The Economist the New York Times and fors and she currently serves on the
president's Council of advisors on science and technology so beyond these
incredibly impressive achievements we asked these three panelists if they would join us today for two reasons the
first is that as you will soon hear the three of them together represent the
range of unexpected challenges that arise in our in the lives of our
alumni everything from professional to personal challenges economic shocks
to Health crisis unexpected events that grip our
families and our children or that strike our careers and our organizations so the
range of what you will hear today is representative of the range of challenges of unexpected experiences
that all of our alumni men and women alike encounter but second we ask these
three women if they would share their experiences and their lessons because as you will hear the ways in which each of
them Rose to the challenges they faced holds lessons for all of us about
resilience about handling adversity and about what we can do when we Face the
unexpected to exercise leadership that makes a difference in the world what we've asked each of them to do is to
take about 10 minutes to share their experiences with us and two or three lessons that they take away I'm going to
ask them to speak in succession so we'll have about 30 minutes of hearing from our panel and then what we'd like to do
is just open it up to a discussion about the unexpected in all of our lives and the lessons that we'd like to share with
one another what I'm going to ask you to do is to um I'm going to be a little bit of a school Mar here or put you back in
the HBS classroom and I'm going to ask that out of uh respect for our panelists
and also out of respect for the conversation and learning that we create together if you could turn off your
electronics your smartphones any potential distraction so we can really take this hour together to learn from
one another and to learn from our panelists so with that Lisa would you start us sure um thank you so much
Joshua I'm very honored to be here today and to have a discussion about dealing with the unexpected just a couple things
before I dive into my unexpected experience I'm going to speak to a professional uh experience because
that's what I was asked to speak about but I acknowledge that in the context of the totality of Our Lives um that's just
one aspect of what we all face and that no matter how um daunting a professional
or business challenge is it certainly doesn't compare to things that impact the well-being of us as as people or our
families so with that said um certainly the experience that rocked my world from a professional point of view was the
final year of maril Lynch the financial crisis and the ultimate merger with Bank of America so to back up and give a
little context Joshua mentioned that I'd worked actually at three Banks before business school and in my second year I
was very deliberate on really choosing a career I may have been the only person in the class of 94 who was picking a
firm in my mind for the next 25 years it seems a little oldfashioned um but I was really picking a company for the long
term and a company that I loved and that I chose because of the culture because of the people and whether it was my 50
colleagues at my wedding or maybe more than 50 that uh came to the funeral when my father passed away as a when I was an
associate um it really was not just my colleagues but my family um and the
spirit of loyalty and Entrepreneurship at that firm was one that I truly loved and so you can imagine um the dismay
when in the fall of 2007 it was actually Halloween I was going home to to go trick-or-treating and I get a call from
our president and says we need to roll up our sleeves and work on raising Equity capital for the firm and having
lived through the end of Drexel I understood that the need for Capital and liquidity in a financial situ in a
financial institution um is a very dire situation and I was part of a small small group um between five or 10 people
that over the next several months truly worked Around the Clock initially raising a slug of about $15 billion of
equity but over the ensuing 15 months over a hundred billion do between asset sales and Equity sales and partially
because it was in a very confidential um small group I couldn't even talk about this with my husband or
my friends and I I really felt the weight of trying to save the company that I loved and 40,000 employees and
their families um and doing everything I could to help raise the capital to make sure it was a good investment for the
new investors that came in in fact I still feel enormous both gratitude and responsibility I recently met with an
investor who's a major shareholder and said I hope you're as long-term as I am because I I do want them to see um an
appropriate return but it was over the next um 10 months that I worked around the clock again trying to um fortify the
company and then in September of 2008 on a very difficult weekend in the financial markets um there was a merger
of maril Lynch with Bank of America which I was actually quite happy to hear because I was smart enough to realize
that being part of a bigger company um would save my company um but it was also a period of a lot of uncertainty and
just to give a sense I did not know personally that I had a job in the new company for 91 days um I was also
pregnant with twins at that time and I can remember to saying this to the same person um who had called me to work on
the capital raise is do I need to go out and and for a job so here I am in a very tumultuous period didn't know if I had a
job in the new company but also I'm a leader of a pretty large team in equity Capital markets and so how do you
balance a period of uncertainty with also making people feel uh okay and that
they should continue to work hard and that there was uh a future um so I think most people now know what happened uh
marilynch and Bank of America merged formally on January 1st of 2009 so uh
we're embarking on our fifth year um and I'm now proud to say that I'm part of Bank of America Mara Lynch and um I'm
still part of a firm which has a lot of remarkable people and does a lot of terrific business um so what are the
lessons that I learned from this period I'd say um three that I would think of one there's a a Haitian proverb that
talks about mountains Beyond mountains and that sometimes you get to the top of the mountain in this case we would raise
this Capital um for Mara Lynch and yet we find out that the whole that had been
created through the mortgage crisis meant that we needed to do more and um I
think what it made me realize is that you have to take things one day at a time keep pushing keep grinding but that
you will persevere and don't get daunted by the fact that there is this very tall
mountain in front of you um and that's something that even to this day I have a much larger job candidly now and it can
seem daunting and very often people say well how do you do it and I say one day at a time and one day at a time you can do it um the second thing is um
something I read about in Jim Collins's book good to great and he talked about um Admiral Stockdale who for those of
you who don't know he was a p in Vietnam for eight years and he talked about which of the
PS um could survive and which frankly couldn't couldn't survive and he said
the folks that said I'll be home by Christmas they didn't make it
because they had set a very high expectation that everything would be okay in a very short period of time the
people that had a view that over the great long term they would Prevail they didn't know what it would be n term they
didn't know if it would be one year or eight Christmases that's how he was able to Prevail and that is something that
during that period from the time of the merger over the next many many months I didn't know what was going to happen
again I didn't even know if I was going to have a job that I could say to people over the long term we going to be okay
um and that I had confident that I could be part of a firm whether Bank of in America or somewhere else where that I
could be part of a team that I was proud of that I could deliver for clients and be part of a culture um that that felt
comfortable for me and then the third thing um was a level of compassion um in a way that um I was
never challenged in this way before because at the time of the merger I led a team that was 77 people and we merged
with the same team at Bank of America which coincidentally had 77 people so 154 uh legal day one post layoffs we
went all the way down to 79 and um that they don't teach your private business school you know um so
no matter what I've been through as a leader the knowledge that each one of
these people um is a brother is a mother is a sister is a daughter is a person is a
neighbor is a provider for their family and um a level of compassion and
understanding that um the ramifications were more than just numbers these were all people and these were all families
um and especially when things are tough um the humanity of the situation and so
um in the ensuing years um we also had significant cuts and
um I I think we're finally done with the the sort of the integration and the layoffs and that's probably the thing
that makes me the happiest is now that we can be in growth mode and we don't have to um uh lay people off but that
that level of uh Challenge and the compassion that came with that was maybe the biggest thing that I learned so with
that I'm going to pause and send it over to is it Kathy or
Melissa after graduating from HBS in 1982 I had a wonderful run in high-tech
um in 1988 when I was two months pregnant with my third child I co-founded the high-tech company and our
family also moved to a larger house two months before our second daughter was born Amy arrived between our startups
employees five and six and new company new house new baby it's amazing what you
can do in your early 30s on 5 hours of sleep at night um and despite a stint of
postpartum depression uh those years proved to be some of the most satisfying creative and Foundation Building of my
life Amy was five when my startup was acquired by a forun 500 and 11 when I
left high-tech um then started teaching high school math I I enrolled her at my
school for what would be a 4-year roller coaster of our three kids her personality was the most like mine and
parenting her was not easy in addition to being incredibly bright she was also
extremely social and I didn't have the street smarts to know all of what that meant having spent most of my life as a
nerd as her behavior became more challenging we had her tested and she was diagnosed with depression anxiety
low self-esteem and later add uh despite starting counseling she started cutting in 9th grade using
marijuana the summer before 10th was already using cocaine as a sophomore and
first tried heroin at 17 I'll never forget the day she arrived at CrossCountry practice high from
smoking weed and we had to meet with the principal then two hours later I had to put on my best game face for five
classes worth of parents coming for back to school night many of whom had ERS on the cross country team there was no HBS
case to prepare me for that surreal evening I found the prescription
painkiller vicadin in Amy's purse during junior year and when she had a positive talkx screen for cocaine I thought I
need an action plan but I'm not sure my HBS approach was all that effective
dealing with a progressive disease we worked with a variety of professionals but most were convinced she was
experimenting and when she started college her academics would Prevail I was heartened when she
transferred from St Louis University to Boston colleges nursing program but on November 16th 2009 I met
with her and her drug counselor and I learned that I was the mother of a heroin
addict but Amy wanted to go to treatment but she would not be able to finish the first semester of her junior
year six days later she began her week of detox then four weeks of rehab she
moved to a residential treatment facility and a few days later snuck in drugs she fadly overdosed on the day
after Christmas week shy of her 21st birthday nobody expected Amy to die she
was Bright Beautiful athletic had a loving family career goals good health
insurance and so many wonderful friends and I thought that his parents
who abstained from illegal substances and were well-educated role models that somehow our family might be immune
wrong in fact one of my HBS colleagues came to Amy's wake and confided that
their son was a recovering heroin addict and shortly thereafter we started a family support group for addiction uh
through the Harvard Business School Association of Boston at a time when conventional
wisdom says to not make any major decisions I decided I needed to scale back back my new school job to Half Time
Amy had been on my case to leave that position for several months when she invited me to the Paul McCartney concert
at Fenway Park the August before she died I declined because we were in crunch mode at work but the school
president would not accommodate my request to go halftime and I resigned two months after Amy died how cruel that
my exit strategy ended up being my daughter's death then door closing opened others I
was fortunate that I had the financial Foundation to pause from the paid Workforce most parents don't have that
option I could mother my then 24-year-old daughter who was shattered at the loss of her little
sister I was conscious that just because my daughter died of an overdose did not mean I had to shift Focus to work in
that area in fact sometimes I long to go back to a corporate cubicle where I could just hide behind a screen if I was
having a bad day but I began telling Amy's story she left the world the gift
of the journals she wrote in rehab which I published last summer when Amy died
several people said you should start a foundation but having done a startup I knew how much work that could be and
I've spent much of the last three years trying to figure out who is already heading up an effective effort where I
might join forces been writing speaking advocating knowing that feels right to
me now and when it no longer makes sense I'll stop I don't have to tell you that
every individual deals with every death differently and in going through A parents worst nightmare I realized I
could just as easily be curled up in bed unable to function so I don't think of
myself as a role model I can just speak to my experience to date I was booed by the friendships I'd
maintained High School classmates my Saturday running group the hbsab programs committee my former students
met all of whom knew Amy and my corporate colleagues in fact the friendships I'd formed in the workplace
have remained among the strongest one colleague wrote the original music to the lyrics I created out of Amy's
journals and another recorded the audio book in her Studio my HBS training also makes me
increasingly concerned about the business Community coming to grips with the enormity of this epidemic and its
threat to our nation's security and economic competitive competitiveness and how some of our best business Minds
Market toxicity to our children including the synthetic marijuana and
candy-like tobacco products you can buy at a convenience store the cost and opportunity costs of the epidemic in
health care the criminal justice system and productivity are staggering consider
the case of a storage company in Ohio having trouble finding enough job candidates who could pass drug tests
or the company whose purchasing manager was buying extra coffee in electronics and selling them on eBay raising
$100,000 to support his painkiller addiction after Amy died former
colleagues opened up with their stories the CEO who had to send their kid to a Wilderness Program because of substance
abuse and attempted suicide the designer now raising her granddaughters because
her daughter killed herself after years of battling alcohol and drugs the top
manager on the factory floor with several heroin addicted siblings the
marketing Guru who hid his cocaine addiction from his parents for over a decade I could go on and
on I'm still learning about the complexities of a Scourge from the geopolitical to the heart of families
I'm still figuring out where I can uniquely add value I feel like this time of my life should be the most
integrative period to make a positive difference currently I'm teaching high school math
the wonderful school where Amy went wanted me back part-time and would love to have me back full-time but I'm
finishing a second book this one for teens and young adults which is a transcription of Amy's adolescent
journals and I continue to attend near andon meetings and tell Amy's story to students parents Educators and
clinicians and I talk individually with neighbors and strangers who seek me out
I was humbled to have to realize that I was ultimately powerless over my daughter's disease coming from HBS were
all trained to be fixers and this was something that wasn't amable to fixing but I also felt really let down by so
many of the professionals I dealt with the good news is that treatment options have gotten much better in the last 10
years I have to cut myself the slack to know that I did the best I could with
what I knew at the time but I was clueless about so much especially how
expensive synthetic heroin I.E prescription painkillers are today's
gateway to cheap illegal heroin and that's why I'm passionate about telling
Amy's story and we'll be happy to share more of what I've learned during the Q&A or after thank you for having
me so you've heard um two Amazing Stories and thank you that was amazing
um my story is we we covered career and jobs and we covered family and my story
story is more about what happens when you yourself um face adversity or a
health issue so what I'm hoping to do is just give you a little overview of my story help you to understand some of the
obstacles that um I was able to overcome and then share some of the the key learnings coming out of that so to share
my story I have to go back um a long way to when I was 37 years old and um I literally remember this moment uh
vividly my husband and I he was a classmate here at HBS section not section A but one of
the sections close by and he and I were um literally put up a Christmas tree and
I remember looking at him and saying how amazing our life was because um we had
just bought this beautiful home we had a gorgeous one-year-old little girl and we both had jobs that we we loved and a few
weeks later I took that Christmas tree down and my entire life had come to a stop
I was diagnosed with a fatal cancer they told me that I would be dead within 3 years and there was absolutely no hope
um in terms of this disease and so um really it was
basically just write your will and movies to be near your family and just get your life in
order so clearly I was 37 I'm now 54 so somehow I was able to beat those odds
and I think um you know to tell you how I ended up doing that it's to talk to you a little bit about
what I did um with both my personal life and my professional life in my personal life you know you
can go one way or the other when something like that happens to you you're either going to pull the covers up over your head or you're going to
decide that you can fight and for me I was really really lucky and you'll hear a lot of themes of motherhood on these
on these panels but you know having a one-year-old that kept you know climbing into my room and climbing into bed with
me it was not really much much of a decision I knew that I would fight um for as long as I possibly could and I
had a vision and my vision was if she was one and they told me I would live
till she was four maybe I had heard that children start remembering their mom at the age of five my vision was I just
wanted to see her turn five that was it if I saw her go to kindergarten I had accepted my death and that was going to
be a huge huge win for me if she looked at a picture down the road and said that was my mom I was so good with that the
second thing that I learned in my personal life was that I was only living a month by month every month they would
draw my blood and tell me how fast the cancer was growing and if it was holding its own it meant I got a month reprieve
but when your children are young like that it's amazing what a month gives you it's a first tooth it's a first laugh
it's a first word and so all those little baby steps just help me keep
going and growing and growing and the third is I learned that I needed to take some risk and when you live with
a death sentence over you you really do automatically take risk so what I ended
up doing was I was raised as an identical twin and I always had a sidekick and I always wanted my little
girl to have a sidekick too so Against All Odds I started interviewing oncologists at the same time that I
interviewed fertility Specialists and um I ended up talking to everybody about invitro
and trying to see what I could do even if it did risk my cancer my goal was just get her a buddy and and that was
good so that was where I was headed personally but professionally um I had a vision there
too and I was really again somewhat lucky I would love to tell you that I started this amazing foundation called
the multiple my Research Foundation because I was this incredibly brilliant woman it wasn't really that way what
happened was everyone that had worked with me in the pharmaceutical industry all the agency
when they found out what had happened all wanted to give money and support the efforts and so I ended up working with
my twin sister and attorney to build a foundation and my vision for that Foundation was just to jump start
research because looking at the pipeline and the reason I knew I would not live more than three years was there was not
a single drug in the pipeline for this form of cancer um and it's you know it's
it's similar to Leukemia and Lymphoma but it it just skewed with demographics that it was completely neglected so my
again was just to to get it to a certain point again hoping that it might prolong my life just a little bit but again I
worked in short-term increments and I kept watching and saying okay I've got great scientists working but they're not
collaborating I think I'll work with them to build a tissue bank and then once we built a tissue bank I thought H
genomic sequencing looks good maybe we'll learn more about the biology of our disease and do genomic sequencing oh
you know what now we've got a drug let's go to clinical trial and I built a clinical Network and show that we could
um build all of our trials faster and better and 10 years go by and we have launched six drugs through FDA um and
more than double the lifespan of our patients and the MMF has become the absolute model in how to do drug
development for all disease-based foundations um I really did end up
taking as much risk in the foundation as I did in my personal life and every time I saw a barrier I just called it I said
this is an issue we developed model against it we funded it and we kept on moving so at this point you're probably
wondering how the whole story ended and the story ends with um my little girl
who was one at the time is now a freshman at Boston College right um and
uh and studying business and marketing there and she is best friends with her
brother who is her little sidekick and he is a sophomore in high school and a great athlete and keeps me incredibly
incredibly busy and I've been married to my classmate for nearly 25 years and we
have um shown the world that you really can change drug development and you can change the nonprofit Sector 10 years ago
I wouldn't have gone there you know I always felt like we were the best of the ugly girls out there because it was so poorly run but now I think there's some
amazing people from Harvard that are you know transforming that entire field and really making a
difference so in terms of what I really want to share with you today it's to
help you to understand that you don't have to get cancer or a fatal disease to look at your life and you don't you
don't have to you can start to look at your own life and reset your vision I I had to reset I said I don't know what's
going to happen to me but when I did that I said what's going to bring me happiness seeing my daughter turn five
and once you start to reset everything you want to do and look at that plan and that Vision in front of you it's amazing
what you see and the second piece is you don't have to transform overnight you
can always go in baby steps one step at a time and make the small changes that
you need that if on Sunday night you really don't want Monday to get there there's something wrong you want to
change that piece of your life and the third thing I really want to share with you is don't wait to do it if there's
things on your mind and things that you can do to make you happier don't wait
because life is not given to you as you've heard today it can be short it can be longer but just make sure you
make the move and take the risks that you want today and in terms of what HBS uh gave
all of us which I think was another part of the question I would say it took us out of our comfort zones for me I came
to HBS I had never had a business course I was a Premed major enrolled in medical school I had no idea what anybody was
talking about the entire first year but I stuck it out and by the end of second year you know you feel so much better
and I think the other pieces HBS also teaches you to do those things I said set a vision take the baby steps and
take risk and finally I am forever indebted to the network that I've built
here the friends that supported me when I started the foundation and you know I come back and work with it being all the
time in the healthc care board as well which is incredibly rewarding thank you I want to thank all
three of you [Applause]
for so candidly sharing your stories and lessons with us um if I can ask the first question and then open it up to
everyone here um what do you think we might do differently at the school to
equip our students for the things we they don't necessarily
control in their life course the things they don't necessarily expect or those dramatic moments when neighbors friends
the people we work with day today are going to lose their jobs and it's on our watch what are some things we might do
differently here at the school to equip people for the unexpected you see I think one of the
great things of um getting cancer is that you're you're pushed to actually
work with counselors and talk with people about what do you want to do where are you going to go if your life is ending and you decide you want to
have another child you know you sit down with the counselor and your husband and try to figure out I don't want to leave
you with two children if I'm going to die in 3 years we didn't take any of those things lightly but I think you
know you know the thing about cancer you never know what's going to happen every time I go back to Dana Farber for three
months I don't know whether I'm relapsing or I'm not relapsing my disease is still fatal and every time you relapse the window gets shorter and
shorter and shorter so I still know that I will die I don't know how soon but I think you know what we have to teach
people is when you when the unexpected is there the stronger your plan is the more you know what you want to do and
the more that you've had those discussions of where you want to go whether it's in your career
with your children all the things that we're talking about for the next 24 hours there's nothing more important
than putting it down on paper and trying to figure it out and I think that was I mean I literally had to sit down and and
write these things out like if if we do have another child if IVF works when do
we go where do we move who's taking care of and you literally have to write it all out I don't think people and it's
not an HBS thing I just don't think people realize the importance of taking what's in your mind And discussing it
and writing it down and getting the plan out there um I
think the overall theme and this often comes in OB cases but maybe in other
areas is just the quality of the relationships that you build uh because that's what's going to get you through
the tough times I you talked about you know classmates and your time and you know quality of relationships with your
colleagues who supported you in personal crisis um you know we can write the best
spreadsheet in the world but um the spreadsheets not going to give us a hug when you know when we're either ecstatic
or whether we've been devastated so making sure to to invest in relationships um you know is definitely
something to keep in mind for me um it's interesting I thought a lot of HBS was about
developing really strong conviction whether it's tackling a case or being a leader and I think with time while I
have appreciation for confidence and ability to get things done I think an
awareness that life does happen and that you know to borrow from Melissa give
yourself some slack because there's also an element of humility and um Humanity
which may be in uh interesting contrast to this Spirit of confidence and never in doubt but you don't know what's going
to come your way and um um in some ways those are the most important
challenges let's open it up thoughts reactions lessons that you've taken from
your own experiences of the unexpected aside from the fact that I
think you have amazing Stories and I feel like we should have a big group hug right now because it really is that
touching you I I'm just going to reflect on some personal experience my experience at HBS was for lack of a
better term arrogance and and I felt very isolated because I came
from big Italian family where everybody you know when when things happen and I don't know if it's because
I've gotten so old that I don't care anymore or if things have changed but I think one of the things that I hope the
school is doing is focusing more on relationships and people and seeing them
as people as opposed to that's my next deal or who do I have to step on in
order to get somewhere else and I know you that and I'm just wondering what if anybody else has had that experience I
feel awkward sort of bringing that out but if anyone else has had that experience so interesting you say that
you know I look at our kids in high school right and I I'll say oh my God my daughter's class was so lovely they were
like the nicest group of kids and then my son's class they're crazy they're just lunatics and um I mean they have
they a culture of just being bad I mean talk about keeping an eye we don't go out in our house we like home all the
time at night and um and so I you know I have to say it's really funny like my class at HBS was so thoughtful and
compassionate and um I don't know whether that happens at HBS that you know year by year maybe the different
classes have a different tone because I've you know I've heard this that some people come back and go God it was awful it was arrogant I had none of that at
all and I don't know maybe it was just I was really lucky and I also you know had an amazing study group that was men and
women and I don't know what it was but we didn't I didn't run into that and I have to say the relationships I built I
mean I still have several classmates on my board they have never these people have never ever let me down so it's kind
of interesting that some I don't know whether you guys ran into that or not I had the exact opposite but I'm sure it
was here yeah I think it was section by section because in my year I had a they
when we went to our second year class where it was our mostly our section they said oh your section has the reputation
for being a family and you guys don't disagree with each other and so we want you to argue with each other but there
